    "target_population": "Ultra-poor and conflict-affected women"

      "cash_amount": "150 USD",

      "is_loan_or_credit": "NO",
      "cash_evidence_citation": "When examining different elements of the intervention, we find that it was in fact the cash transfer of 150 USD that had a significant impact on reducing the overlapping deprivations, but not the group dynamics training element."
    },
    "component_b_assets": {
      "component_b_present": true,

      "direct_provision": "YES",
      "assets_evidence_citation": "Using data from a randomised controlled trial (Blattman et al., 2016), this paper assesses the impact of a human capital and cash transfer intervention-Women's Income Generating Support (WINGS) program-on the multiple dimensions of (dis)empowerment faced by conflict-affected and ultra-poor women."

      "psychosocial well-being",
      "physical health"
    ],
    "outcomes_evidence_citation": "We find that the WINGS program reduced multidimensional disempowerment by 13.6% on average compared to the control group's endline mean; however, at endline, the beneficiaries still experienced at least 20% of joint deprivation simultaneously. | By analysing the censored headcount ratios of the deprivations, i.e., the percentage of women deprived in a certain indicator and have a cumulative deprivation score above the cut-off k, we find that the intervention was successful at reducing food insecurity, income and assets deprivation and increased control over household resources. | In terms of physical health and psychosocial well-being, our results are inconclusive."
    ,
    "study_design": "Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)",
    "design_evidence_citation": "Using data from a randomised controlled trial (Blattman et al., 2016), this paper assesses the impact of a human capital and cash transfer intervention-Women's Income Generating Support (WINGS) program-on the multiple dimensions of (dis)empowerment faced by conflict-affected and ultra-poor women in two of the most war-affected districts in Northern Uganda: Kitgum and Gulu. | Across the 120 villages in the study, treatment was randomly assigned at the village level, and in Phase II, the intervention was extended to the initial waitlisted control group.",
